did.unittitle: Somerset, Mass. First Christian Union Church records, 1840-1912.
did.abstract: The First Christian Union Church and Society were formed in the Pottersville, Somerset area as early as 1838 by a "Christian Band" comprising thirty members, though the church was not officially incorporated until 1911. In 1939 the name was changed to the Congregational Christian Church of Somerset Centre. These records consists of three bound volumes, including the earliest record books of the church and society, respectively, and a book of meeting minutes and bylaws of the Ladies' Industrial Association.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: In 1838, a group of thirty, known as the "Christian Band", signed a covenant to organize a church community in the village of Pottersville in Somerset, Massachusetts. The covenant led, in November 1840, to the construction of a meetinghouse. On May 26, 1841, a ceremony was held for the dedication of the new meetinghouse and its acceptance into the Christian denomination. Later that year William Shurtleff was called to be the first pastor of the religious society known as the First Christian Union Society in Somerset, Massachusetts.

It was not until 1911 that the First Christian Church, as it came to be known, was incorporated under the laws of Massachusetts. In 1939, a vote was taken to change the name to the Congregational Christian Church of Somerset Centre. The church is still active today as the Congregational Christian Church of Somerset and has been a member of the United Church of Christ since 1957.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of three bound volumes, including the earliest record books and other materials from the First Christian Union Church of Somerset, Massachusetts. The first volume, in chronological order by start date, is a record book for the church and society containing membership information, vital statistics such as baptisms, admissions, dismissions, disciplinary cases, and deaths, as well as meeting minutes pertaining to the selection of church officers and pastors, finances, and a chronicle of church events. The second volume is a record book for the society, containing a copy of the church's covenant and administrative records, including committee assignments and correspondence. The third volume is an administrative record book kept by the Ladies' Industrial Association which includes bylaws and meeting minutes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials have been arranged in chronological order by start date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume contains the records of the Ladies Industrial Association of the First Church, a group which evolved from the former Ladies Union Sewing Society. The organization operated partly as a ladies' auxiliary for the church, as well as a bible study group and social club. Records include a roster of membership, meetings minutes, financial records, and details of sewing and knitting projects.
